Incident.Summary: DWI/DUI- 23-050- a 21 902 A2 : (Driving, Attempting To Drive) Vehicle While Under the Influence Of Alcohol Per Se/ Sinhasunkage, Sadip

IncidentSuppNarrative.NarrativeText: 23-MSP-010913 G-22 is equipped with a mobile recording device/ This incident was captured by TFC. Loudins Body Worn Camera Incident: DUI 23-050/TA-21-902 (a1i) Driving under the influence of alcohol per se Incident Date/time: March 26, 2023 at approximately 2343 hours into March 27, 2023. Incident location: Bachman Valley Road and Eckard Road in Westminster, Carroll County Maryland. Attachments: Intoximeter worksheet DR 15 Advise of rights MSP for 33- Result for test for alcohol concentration DR-15 A Officer certification and order of suspension Citations Notice to Appear Copy of drivers license MVA printouts QUALIFICATIONS: Maryland State Police Academy (June 2014) I am trained to administer Standardized Field Sobriety Tests through NHTSA and the Maryland State Police. A.R.I.D.E.: Advanced Roadside Impaired Driving Enforcement (November 2017) Accused: Sinhasunkage, Sadip Kavinda Gun DOB: 11/04/1997 Address: 410 Poole Road, Apt T2 Vehicle in Motion (Phase I) On March 26, 2023, at approximately 2343hours, I, TFC. Loudin #6490, was advised by dispatch that Sgt. Shipley #2861 was on a traffic stop, and he believed the driver to be impaired. I responded to Sgt. Shipleys traffic stop, located at Bachman Valley Road and Eckard Road in Westminster, Carroll County Maryland. I made contact with Sgt. Shipley, who advised that the vehicle was all over the road and observed a few traffic violations prior to stopping the vehicle. He noted that the vehicle could not maintain its lane, failed to drive right of center and the lights on the vehicle kept coming on and going off. He then advised that when he made contact, he immediately could tell that the driver was impaired by his appearance. Sgt. Shipley also stated that he smelled the odor of burnt marijuana coming from the vehicle. Contact (Phase II) I made contact with the driver at the driver side window, I introduced myself and advised that the traffic stop was being audibly and visually recorded. I advised the driver that Sgt. Shipley was the one who intialy pulled him over, however his shift was coming to an end and requested another unit to continue the traffic stop. I asked the driver for his name and date of birth, the driver then identified himself as Sinhasunkage, Sadip Kavinda Gun (DOB: 11/04/1997) by a presented Maryland Drivers License. I asked Mr. Sinhasunkage if he had consumed any alcohol, and he advised that he had consumed alcohol at his home. I also asked if he smoked marijuana and at first he denied smoking marijuana,but then admitted to smoking and drinking alcohol approximately forty minutes prior. He advised that he normally smokes in the car. I detected the odor of burnt marijuana and a faint odor of an alcoholic beverage coming from the vehicle. I observed his eyes to be blood shot and his movements and reaction to my questions to be delayed or slow. Pre Arrest Screening I requested Mr. Sinhasunkage to exit the vehicle. He then put his hand on the gear shifter and it appeared as though he was going to try and leave. I told him not to and he changed the shifter from park to drive. I again told him not to leave, and he looked at me when I said no and then changed the gear back to park. Mr. Sinhasunkage then exited the vehicle. Mr. Sinhasunkage appeared unsteady on his feet outside the vehicle. I continued to detect the odor of burnt marijuana and the odor of an alcoholic beverage coming from Mr. Sinhasunkage breath and person. I requested Mr. Sinhasunkage to perform Field Sobriety Testing, to which he complied. I asked Mr. Sinhasunkage the following questions: What alcohol did you drink? He advised he drank beer I asked Mr. Sinhasunkage if he had any gum in his mouth. He did not have any gum, but I did observe green filament on his tongue. Glasses or contacts- No glasses or contacts Medications- No medications Injuries- No injuries Mr. Sinhasunkage advised that he used marijuana for personal use and was not in themedical marijuana program. Horrizontal Gaze Nystagmus (HGN) (6/6 clues observed) I requested Mr. Sinhasunkage place his feet together and to place his hands down at his side. I advised Mr. Sinhasunkage that I would be checking his eyes. I instructed Mr. Sinhasunkage to follow the tip of my pen with his eyes, and not to move his head. I asked if he understood the instructions, and he replied yes. He also advised that he could see the pen. margin-bottom:11px">Resting Nystagmus-not present margin-bottom:11px">Equal Pupil size-both pupils were the same size margin-bottom:11px">Equal tracking-both eyes displayed equal tracking margin-bottom:11px">Lack of Smooth Pursuit-present, His eyes noticeably jerked margin-bottom:11px">Distinct and sustained Nystagmus at maximum deviation-Present margin-left:16px">Onset of Nystagmus prior to 45 degrees-present Vertigal Gaze Nystagmus was observed. I continued to detect the odor of an alcoholic beverage coming from Mr. Sinhasunkage as well as a strong odor of marijuana. His eyes were noticeably blood shot, and he swayed from front to back during the test. Walk and Turn (WAT)- 5/8 clues observed I requested Mr. Sinhasunkage to stand with his left foot on the line (straight-line, white solid fog line) and to place his right foot in front of his left foot. Mr. Sinhasunkage put his left foot in front of his right. He was instructed to remain in that position, while I explained and demonstrated the test. Mr. Sinhasunkage was advised that he would be taking nine heel to toe steps on the line, turn while keeping his lead foot planted and to take nine more heel to toe steps. He was told to keep his hands down at his side, look at his feet and to count his steps out loud. He was then advised that if he stepped off-line at any point he would get back into position and to continue the test until completed. He advised that he understood the test. Mr. Sinhasunkage was wearing a black jacket, blue jeans and flip-flops, he advised were his sisters. I asked Mr. Sinhasunkage if he was comfortable wearing the flip-flops for this test, and he elected to remove the flip-flops. The white solid shoulder line was used and was free from debris. Instructional phase: Nothing observed Walking phase: margin-left:16px">Steps off-line-Mr. Sinhasunkage stepped off-line on step one (1), placing his right foot down directly next to him and then in front of his left. He then started the test over. margin-left:16px">Stops walking-Stopped the test after one step and restarted. ( He had difficulty getting back into position). margin-left:16px">Raised arms for balance-Step one he used his left arm and raised it more than six inches margin-left:16px">Missed heel to toe contact on one to nine- Mr. Sinhasunkage did not touch heel to toe on the first nine steps (all twelve steps he took). Each step, his feet were approximately six to twelve inches apart. The second nine steps he also missed heel to toe contact on all steps (all ten steps he took) margin-left:16px">Improper number of steps- Twelve steps taken on the first nine steps. Ten steps taken on the second nine steps. One Leg Stand (OLS)- 3/4 clues observed Mr. Sinhasunkage was requested to place his feet together and to keep his hands down at his side. I advised Mr. Sinhasunkage that he when he was told to begin, he would raise whichever foot he chooses approximately six inches off the ground, keep his legs straight, point his toe and would be counting in one thousands. He was advised that if he put his foot down, he was to pick it back up and continue where he left off, until I advised him to stop. Mr. Sinhasunkage acknowledge that he understood. Mr. Sinhasunkage used his right foot to balance and raised his left foot. margin-bottom:11px">Raised arms for balance-Mr. Sinhasunkage lost balance immediately and raised his left arm more than six inches. He also raised his left arm for balance again at approximately twenty-six seconds (26) margin-bottom:11px">Puts foot down-Mr. Sinhasunkage put his foot down immediately upon raising it at the start of the test and took a few seconds before raising it again. At approximately seventeen seconds, Mr. Sinhasunkage put his foot down again. margin-bottom:11px"> Sways - Mr. Sinhasunkage swayed within the first ten seconds from left to right before losing his balance. Mr. Sinhasunkage was offered the Preliminary breath test. He accepted the test and blew BrAC of .13 per 210 milliliters of breath. Mr. Sinhasunkage was placed under arrest at approximately 0014 hours for driving under the influence of alcohol. He was transported to the Maryland State Police Westminster barrack. Mr. Sinhasunkage was read his Dr-15 Advice of Rights at approximately 0052 hours, and he elected to take the breath test. Sgt. Gibson #5039, provided Mr. Sinhasunkage with instructions and conducted the test. Mr. Sinhasunkage was found to have a .17 Breath Alcohol content per 210 Milliliters of breath. Mr. Sinhasunkage was charged with the following charges: TA 21 301 (a) Failure to drive vehicle on right half of roadway when required. TA 21- 201 (a1) Driver failure to obey properly placed traffic control device instructions. TA 21-901.1 (b) Negligent driving vehicle in careless and imprudent manner endangering property, life and person TA 21-901 (a) Reckless driving vehicle in a wanton and willful disregard for safety of persons and property TA 21-902(b1i) Driving while impaired by alcohol TA 21-902 (a1i) Driving under the influence of alcohol TA 21-902 (a1ii) Driving under the influence of alcohol per se TA 21-901 (c1i) Driving vehicle while so far impaired by alcohol and drugs, cannot drive safely. Mr. Sinhasunkage signed and was provided a copy of the District Court Notice to Appear Form Notice to Counsel, DR- 15 Advice of Rights, DR-15 A, MSP form 33 and the citations listed above. He was released from the Westminster Barrack to his family. All events occurred in Carroll County Maryland. Case closed on arrest
